{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3606466,"name":"","username":"ip2theking","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ip2theking/{size}/261812_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-28T20:48:06.859Z","cooked":"

I want to design and build a mini Swerve chassis for less than $200, any ideas about what to control it with and what motors to use (maybe outdated FRC electronics). Any help would be appreciated.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-04-28T20:48:06.859Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":342,"readers_count":341,"score":103.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500783,"topic_slug":"diy-swerve-minibot","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62585,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/diy-swerve-minibot/500783/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3606476,"name":"Andrew Schreiber","username":"Andrew_Schreiber","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/andrew_schreiber/{size}/209563_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-28T20:55:36.759Z","cooked":"

You won’t be near FRC scale with that.

Printables.com

Omnidirectional XRP Robot by WildWilly | Download free STL model |...

Swerve drivetrain for XRP | Download free 3D printable STL models

Is pretty close, but it’s going to be a whole new world of controls.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-04-28T20:55:36.759Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":335,"readers_count":334,"score":97.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500783,"topic_slug":"diy-swerve-minibot","display_username":"Andrew Schreiber","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.printables.com/model/951372-omnidirectional-xrp-robot/comments/2295432","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Omnidirectional XRP Robot by WildWilly | Download free STL model | Printables.com","clicks":71}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4297,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Here we go again"},"post_url":"/t/diy-swerve-minibot/500783/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3606495,"name":"","username":"FinIce","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/finice/{size}/228172_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-28T21:23:38.568Z","cooked":"

IF you really want FRC scale, the closest you would come would be with some combination of microprocessors (pi, Arduino, etc) with NerdSwerve and some donated CIM motors and Talons. However, be aware that connectors, batteries, switches, and other hardware to make it probably eat up your budget before any other building can begin.

(I just found that thread not even a minute ago)

First question we should be asking is why do you want to build a mini swerve bot? Is it to practice design and building skills. Looks like 1701 is already a swerve enabled team so more than likely building the swerve mini bot is not to develop code for next year.

Please check out nerdswerve.com. One of our students, who is now a graduating senior, went down this road and documented his work on that website. It has code and CAD.

Please reach out if you have questions. My one word of advice is to have the end in mind. CIMs and mini CIM are fairly easily gotten these days because they are pretty useless for competition robots. If you spend all your time developing a platform around these types of motors, you might find that all the things you learn may not be directly applicable to a competition robot.

Best of luck.
